dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: Hi, my name's Patricia.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: Patricia, nice to meet you. Where are you a student at?

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: I am starting my senior year now at NYU.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: Oh nice. And what have you been studying the past few years?

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: I studied computer science and data science.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: If you were chatting with a non-CS, non-data science friend of yours, how would you explain to them what an algorithm is?

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: Some kind of systematic way of solving a problem, or like a set of steps to kind of solve a certain problem you have.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: So, you probably recall learning topics like binary search versus linear search, and the like.

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: Yeah.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: So, I've come here complete with a actual chalkboard with some magnetic numbers on it here. How would you tell a friend to sort these?

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: I think one of the first things we learned was something called bubble sort. It was kind of like focusing on smaller bubbles I guess I would say of the problem, like looking at smaller segments rather than the whole thing at once.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: What is I think very true about what you're hinting at is that bubble sort really focuses on local, small problems rather than taking a step back trying to fix the whole thing, let's just fix the obvious problems in front of us. So, for instance, when we're trying to get from smallest to largest, and the first two things we see are eight followed by one, this looks like a problem 'cause it's out of order. So, what would be the simplest fix, the least amount of work we can do to at least fix one problem?

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: Just switch those two numbers 'cause one is obviously smaller than eight.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: Perfect. So, we just swap those two then.

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: You would switch those again.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: Yeah, so that further improves the situation and you can kind of see it, that the one and the two are now in place. How about eight and six?

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: Switch it again.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: Switch those again. Eight and three?

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: Switch it again.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: And conversely now the one and the two are closer to, and coincidentally are exactly where we want them to be. So, are we done?

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: No.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: Okay, so obviously not, but what could we do now to further improve the situation?

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: Go through it again but you don't need to check the last one anymore because we know that number is bubbled up to the top.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: Yeah, because eight has indeed bubbled all the way to the top. So, one and two?

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: Yeah, keep it as is.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: Okay, two and six?

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: Keep it as is.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: Okay, six and three?

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: Then you switch it.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: Okay, we'll switch or swap those. Six and four?

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: Swap it again.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: Okay, so four, six and seven?

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: Keep it.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: Okay. Seven and five?

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: Swap it.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: Okay. And then I think per your point, we're pretty darn close. Let's go through once more. One and two?

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: Keep it.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: Two three?

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: Keep it.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: Three four?

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: Keep it.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: Four six?

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: Keep it.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: Six five?

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: And then switch it.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: All right, we'll switch this. And now to your point, we don't need to bother with the ones that already bubbled their way up. Now we are a hundred percent sure it's sorted.

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: Yeah.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: And certainly the search engines of the world, Google and Bing and so forth, they probably don't keep webpages in sorted order 'cause that would be a crazy long list when you're just trying to search the data. But there's probably some algorithm underlying what they do and they probably similarly, just like we, do a bit of work upfront to get things organized even if it's not strictly sorted in the same way so that people like you and me and others can find that same information. So, how about social media? Can you envision where the algorithms are in that world?

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: Maybe for example like TikTok, like the For You page, 'cause those are like recommendations, right? It's sort of like Netflix recommendations except more constant because it's just every video you scroll, it's like that's a new recommendation basically. And it's based on what you've liked previously, what you've saved previously, what you search up. So, I would assume there's some kind of algorithm there kind of figuring out like what to put on your For You page.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: Absolutely. Just trying to keep you presumably more engaged. So, the better the algorithm is, the better your engagement is, maybe the more money the company then makes on the platform and so forth. So, it all sort of feeds together. But what you're describing really is more artificially intelligent, if I may, because presumably there's not someone at TikTok or any of these social media companies saying, If Patricia likes this post, then show her this post. If she likes this post, then show her this other post. Because the code would sort of grow infinitely long and there's just way too much content for a programmer to be having those kinds of conditionals, those decisions being made behind the scenes. So, it's probably a little more artificially intelligent. And in that sense you have topics like neural networks, and machine learning which really describe taking as input things like what you watch, what you click on, what your friends watch, what they click on, and sort of trying to infer from that instead, what should we show Patricia or her friends next?

dialogue.author: Explainee
dialogue.text: Oh, okay. Yeah. Yeah. That makes like the distinction more... Makes more sense now.

dialogue.author: Explainer
dialogue.text: Nice. Yeah.
